title: Photos: 2020 Women’s March
description: Like the first protest only days after the inauguration of President Trump, the national Women's March will take place in Washington, D.C., with sister marches around the country.
text: Photos: 2020 Women’s MarchSC, Ala. sites look back Betty Ford honored 20 years till the next one Dream Chaser detailsU.S. Elections Sports Entertainment Life Money Tech Travel OpinionONLY AT USA TODAY:Newsletters For Subscribers From the Archives Crossword eNewspaper Magazines      Investigations Podcasts Video Humankind Just Curious Best-selling BooklistOUR PORTFOLIO:10Best Reviewed Coupons Homefront Blueprint Best Auto InsuranceBest Pet Insurance Best Travel Insurance Best Credit Cards Best CD Rates Best Personal Loans Home Internet NATIONPhotos: 2020 Women’s MarchUSA TODAYOlivia Berke, 15, a sophomore at Walnut Hills High School, attends the Women's March at Sawyer Park in Cincinnati, Ohio, hosted by United We Stand, Saturday, Jan. 18, 2020. The Women's March started the day after President Donald Trump was inaugurated on January 20, 2017. The movement supports women's policies, immigration reform, reproductive rights, LGBTQ rights, racial equality, freedom of religion, workers' rights and tolerance.Liz Dufour, The Enquirer/ USA TODAY NetworkWomen’s March Chicago participants walk past the Art Institute toward Federal Plaza on Jan. 18, 2020.Grace Hauck, USA TODAYProtesters with posters supporting women at the Women's March ATX at the Capitol of Texas in Austin on Saturday, Jan. 18, 2020.Lola Gomez, Austin American-Statesman/ USA TODAY NetworkA large crowd takes part in the Women's March at Sawyer Park in Cincinnati, Ohio, hosted by United We Stand, Saturday, Jan. 18, 2020. The walk took them down Second Street, past the Cincinnati Reds and The Banks. The Women's March started the day after President Donald Trump was inaugurated on January 20, 2017.Liz Dufour, The Enquirer/ USA TODAY NetworkSnow falls as participants in the Women's March in New York City make their way down Sixth Avenue on Saturday, Jan. 18, 2020.Michael Karas, NorthJersey.com/ USA TODAY NetworkLydia Caserez holds a poster supporting women at the Women's March ATX at the Capitol of Texas in Austin on Saturday, Jan. 18, 2020.Lola Gomez, Austin American-Statesman/ USA TODAY NetworkSnow falls as members of Gays Against Guns NY make their way down Sixth Avenue in the New York City Women's March on Saturday, Jan. 18, 2020.Michael Karas, NorthJersey.com/ USA TODAY NetworkMarchers gather for the 2020 Women's March on Jan. 18, 2020 in Washington D.C. Organizers expected up to 10,000 participants, a far cry from the 100,000 who attended the last year.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAYFrom left, Angelita Guerra, Julieta Garibay and Cecilia Hernandez hold posters supporting women and Elizabeth Warren at the Women's March ATX at the Capitol of Texas in Austin on Saturday, Jan. 18, 2020.Lola Gomez, Austin American-Statesman/ USA TODAY NetworkProtesters with posters supporting women at the Women's March ATX at the Capitol of Texas in Austin on Saturday, Jan. 18, 2020.Lola Gomez, Austin American-Statesman/ USA TODAY NetworkEleanor Towe, 8, of Madeira, with her mom, Ariana, walk during the Women's March at Sawyer Park in Cincinnati, Ohio, hosted by United We Stand, Saturday, Jan. 18, 2020.Liz Dufour, The Enquirer/ USA TODAY NetworkMarchers gather for the 2020 Women's March on Jan. 18, 2020 in Washington. Organizers are expecting around 10,000 participants, a far cry from the 100,000 who attended the last year.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAYMarchers gather for the 2020 Women's March on Jan. 18, 2020 in Washington.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAYWomen’s March Chicago participants leave signs across from Trump Tower on Jan. 18, 2020.Grace Hauck, USA TODAYDemonstrators take part in the 4th annual Women's March, in New York on January 18, 2020.JOHANNES EISELE, AFP Via Getty ImagesMarchers gather for the 2020 Women's March on Jan.18, 2020 in Chicago. It was one of several marches held around the country.Grace Hauck, USA TODAYThousands gather for the 2020 Women's March on Jan. 18, 2020 in Washington D.C.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAYMarchers gather for the 2020 Women's March on Jan. 18, 2020 in Washington D.C.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAYDemonstrators take part in the 4th annual Women's March in New York on January 18, 2020.JOHANNES EISELE, AFP Via Getty ImagesDemonstrators gather for the 4th annual Women's March in New York on January 18, 2020.JOHANNES EISELE, AFP Via Getty ImagesPeople participate in the annual Women's March on January 18, 2020 in New York City. In the fourth iteration of the Womens March, thousands are marching in cities across the world to draw focus on immigration, climate change and abortion rights.Yana Paskova, Getty ImagesThousands sing the Chilean protest anthem “A rapist is your path” before beginning to march through downtown Washington D.C. as part of the 2020 Women’s March on Jan. 18, 2020.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAYThousands gathered in sleet and rain to march through downtown Washington D.C. at the 2020 Women’s March on Jan. 18, 2020.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAYParticipants ride a bus chartered by Northern Colorado Now as they head to the Denver Women's March.Bethany Baker, The Coloradoan-USA TODAY NetworkMarchers gather for the 2020 Women's March on Jan.18, 2020 in Chicago. It was one of several marches held around the country.Grace Hauck, USA TODAYMarchers gather for the 2020 Women's March on Jan.18, 2020 in Chicago.Grace Hauck, USA TODAYMarchers gather for the 2020 Women's March on Jan.18, 2020 in Washington. Organizers are expecting around 10,000 participants, a far cry from the 100,000 who attended the last year.Joshua Bote, USA TODAYMarchers gather for the 2020 Women's March on Jan. 18, 2020 in Washington D.C.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAYThe all-women Afro-Brazilian percussion band Batala Washington helped lead the 2020 Women's March through the streets of downtown Washington D.C. on Jan. 18, 2020.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAYA trio of baby Trump balloons float above the crowd gathering for the 2020 Women's March on Jan. 18, 2020 in Washington D.C.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAYElaine Kuckertz, of Washington D.C., carries Meatloaf through the 2020 Women's March on Jan. 18, 2020 in Washington D.C.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAYTamesha Bonaparte, center, of the Setalcott Nation in Long Island, N.Y., gather for the 2020 Women's March on Jan. 18, 2020 in Washington D.C.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAYMarchers gather for the 2020 Women's March on Jan. 18, 2020 in Washington D.C.Hannah Gaber, USA TODAY4th annual Women's March participants walk down 8th Street South in Naples, Fla. on Saturday, Jan. 18, 2020.Jon Austria/Naples Daily News US, Naples Daily News/ USA TODAY NetworkCori Craciun of Naples joins participants in the 4th annual Women's March as they make their way down 8th Avenue South in Naples, Fla. on Saturday, Jan. 18, 2020.Jon Austria/Naples Daily News US, Naples Daily News/ USA TODAY NetworkThe Brevard Women's March, held Jan. 18, in conjunction with Saturday's national marches, formed up near the Eau Gallie Causeway Boat Ramp, and proceeded over the Causeway towards the Melbourne mainland before returning to the starting point. Also gathered nearby was a group of conservatives, many carrying flags and signs in support of President Trump. At some points, the opposing sides were amongst each other.TIM SHORTT, FLORIDA TODAY/USA TODAY NetworkFeatured Weekly AdAbout Us Newsroom Staff Ethical Principles Responsible Disclosure Request a Correction Press Releases Accessibility Sitemap Subscription Terms & Conditions Terms of Service Privacy Policy Your Privacy ChoicesContact Us Help Center Manage Account Give Feedback Get Home Delivery eNewspaper USA TODAY Shop USA TODAY Print Editions Licensing & Reprints Advertise With Us Careers Internships Support Local BusinessNews Tips Submitting letters to the editor Podcasts Newsletters Mobile Apps Facebook X Instagram LinkedIn Threads Post YouTube Reddit Flipboard10Best Reviewed Best-selling Booklist Jobs Sports Betting Sports Weekly Studio Gannett Classifieds Coupons Homefront Home Internet Blueprint Auto Insurance Pet Insurance Travel Insurance Credit Cards Banking Personal Loans LLC Formation Payroll Software© 2024 USA TODAY, a division of Gannett Satellite Information Network, LLC.
